thread.title: Ten things to do off the beaten track on an autumn day out in West Sussex
thread.title_full: Ten things to do off the beaten track on an autumn day out in West Sussex

title: Ten things to do off the beaten track on an autumn day out in West Sussex
text: Ten things to do off the beaten track on an autumn day out in West Sussex Ten things to do off the beaten track on an autumn day out in West Sussex GO on safari, discover how the Tudors cooked and try top sparkling wine on a vineyard tour. PUBLISHED: 00:00, Thu, Oct 8, 2015 | UPDATED: 17:40, Thu, Oct 8, 2015 GETTY Animals roam around the compound of Knepp Castle Estate 1. Go on a wildlife safari. Knepp Castle Estate is one of the largest re-wilding projects in lowland Europe. Take a half-day dawn or dusk vehicle-based safari around the 3,500 acres, seeing herds of longhorn cattle, Exmoor ponies, Tamworth pigs, red and fallow deer as they roam freely in their own savannah. www.kneppsafaris.co.uk 2. Tour a vineyard for free. Sip on sparkling wines on a trip to Nutbourne Vineyards. There is no entrance charge and visitors can walk among the vines and visit the windmill tower. For a small fee, join in a group tours of the vineyard and winery plus organised tastings in the wine lodge. www.nutbournevineyards.com 3. Meet Britain's largest Rhododendron. Set in 93 acres of woodland, South Lodge country house hotel in Horsham has a tradition of fine dining. At the helm in The Pass restaurant is Michelin-starred chef Matt Gillan from BBC's Great British Menu. Pop in to South Lodge for a luxury afternoon tea and take a walk around the grounds where you'll find the largest single-stemmed Rhododendron in Britain, which is over 150 years old. www.southlodgehotel.co.uk GETTY Weald and Downland Museum 4. Cook up a treat in the Tudor kitchen at the Weald and Downland Museum. Set in 40 acres of rural landscape, the buildings tell the stories of the men, women and children who lived and worked in them over a 600-year period. There is a regular programme of demonstrations, including cooking in a Tudor kitchen; milling flour in the working watermill and blacksmithing in a Victorian smithy. www.wealddown.co.uk 5. Take a guided walk in the South Downs. Footprints of Sussex organise a programme of local guided walks in the South Downs National Park. One example takes in the small farms north of Steyning, with a 'get together' in a pub garden after the walk. www.footprintsofsussex.co.uk 6. Climb up to Iron Age Cissbury Ring. The National Trust's Cissbury Ring is the most historic in the South Downs and the second largest hill fort in the country, with far-reaching views to the coast. Rare plants such as the round headed rampion, known as the 'Pride of Sussex', thrive here. www.nationaltrust.org.uk/cissbury-ring/ GETTY Aerial view of Horsham 7. Explore Sussex Prairies.. Garden fans will love it. Created in 2008 by a husband and wife team, this eight acre garden has a series of interlocking arcs of natural-style borders, surrounded by mature oak trees. It's a very British twist on the Dutch new wave perennial style of planting. Look out for the sculptures and artwork too and have lunch in the tea shop. www.sussexprairies.co.uk 8. Step into a bygone era. Amberley Working Museum is dedicated to the South East's industrial heritage. The 36 acre site includes a print workshop and wheelwrights, vintage transport and the Southdown bus collection. A number of resident crafts people still work to traditional methods and there is a regular programme of special events. www.amberleymuseum.co.uk/ 9. Tour a medieval house. Pretty, Grade 1-listed St Mary's House and Gardens in the village of Bramber was built as a medieval pilgrim inn by the bishop of Winchester, and is a still lived-in home today. The timber-framed house has fine panelled Interiors include an Elizabethan "Painted Room", while the gardens include animal topiary, a Living Fossil Tree, ' Monk's Walk' and floral borders. www.stmarysbramber.co.uk 10. Eat like a local. Every Thursday and Saturday, Horsham hosts one of the largest local produce markets in the south which is a showcase for the many locally based and artisan producers located within a 40 mile radius of the town including breads, pies, vegetables, craft beers, cakes and chocolate. www.visithorsham.co.uk Related articles
